job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Urbana, IL
pros: Great resources for a graduate student. Facilities are extensive and accessible. Many very talented and intelligent people. Lot of ability to work independently and also good collaborations.
cons: Graduate student life challenging but manageable. Top tier university demands extremely high quality work and pressure to publish in high end journals with high impact.

pros: World class engineering program. The opportunity to mentor and work with top students from around the globe.  The university is within 2-3 hours from big cities (e.g., Chicago, St. Louis, Indianapolis).  Very generous vacation package.
cons: Recent scandals as well as buget cuts from the state is affecting the schools reputation. It appears as though the state of Illinois is not very vested on ensuring that  their flagship institution remains on top.

pros: Perfect place to focus on scientific research. Large campus and great area. Lots of inter-departmental collaborations.
cons: Not much to do for fun. Not very safe at night. Very small city in the middle of the corn field. The state government doesn't have funding to support the university. The secretaries are very lazy to get your HR stuff done.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Urbana, IL
pros: I was a TA in the physics department.  The guidance and enthusiasm of the course leaders made being a TA an enjoyable experience.
cons: Proctoring exams in the evening was not very pleasant but this did not happen too often.  The class sizes are getting larger which inhibits teaching effectiveness.

review_title: A very good position, but expect additional responsibilities outside of a typical postdoc.
pros: Decent salary for the location and job description.  Independence from PIs.  Have a small stipend for personal research.
cons: A lot of additional responsibility above and beyond a typical postdoc.  Stipend is not additional salary; purchases are essentially university (or state) property, such as computer equipment, etc.  Research is highly dependent on the theme of the research.

pros: It depends on which professor you are working with. Choose your adviser wisely! I worked in the ECE department. The pay is better than other departments, but still not as good (see cons). The good thing in the ECE department is that you are almost guaranteed to get a TA, as they provide positions for who decided to switch groups.
cons: Low pay. Possibly bad supervisor. Equipment depends on the lab/group you join. Otherwise no complaints.

review_title: Working for the University of Illinois as a Researcher has been a great experience and it is a dream come true.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Champaign, IL
pros:
The working environment has been very flexible yet challenging.
Provides detail insight on Research and how a modern day sophisticated National Project is dealt with.
Work environment in the Research lab is really friendly with a learning yet competitive environment all around.
Salary and benefits are very reasonable.
cons: The labwork is very time-consuming and needs a lot of perfection.

pros:
Great opportunity to build relationships.
Ability to advance career in recreations, sport, tourism, or athletics
Great opportunity to take advantage of employee perks.
cons:
Extremely stressful as a premed college student
Demanding work & life commitments; job is truly a balancing act. 
Very low wages; especially for the amount of money the facility makes
Lacks diversity

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Urbana, IL
pros: Flexible working hours means you can work some other hours a day, or at night, giving you a flexible schedule
cons: Typical to any graduate assistantship position, the hours of work are generally higher than the hours you are paid for. The rate is also low. Overall this means: cheap labor for overworked graduate student.

pros: Very theoretical place, and your teacher/supervisor will push you learn a lot, gaining a lot of skills and experience
cons: if you are working at poor department, they all care about pushing you out ASAP. They don't care about your status after graduation. Graduate, and then we don't need to worry about what the heck you will do after graduate. We just need the numbers of graduates to make our department look good.

pros:
Amount of work is generally manageable
Pay is reasonable for the kind of work done
Generally given free reins over how to complete the work
cons: Workload may vary significantly from week to week, some weeks the work can be very difficult to complete within the deadline but other weeks the workload may be fairly light. However, in generally it is generally fair and would not take up a huge amount of time.

review_title: Awesome research opportunities as undergraduate research assistant
job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in Urbana, IL
pros: A lot of opportunities are provided. You can be surrounded by smart, friendly and enthusiastic people. Freshmen and Sophomores can get a research pretty easily if one works hard enough.
cons: Sometimes, there are too many people seeking to work or to do research under famous professors just like you. Also, you have to work yourself out to find opportunities that suits you when provided opportunities are all filled.

pros: Friendly atmosphere, great employer, freedom to do whatever you feel needs to be done as an employee.  Very great employer-employee relationships.
cons: There really isn't much to say with cons.  Perhaps too little vacation time, but even that aspect of UIUC isn't so bad.

job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in Urbana, IL
pros: There are lots of opportunities for undergraduates to get involved with current research. Graduate students give the students a lot of independence with the projects.
cons: It can be hard to balance working so many hours every week with a full class schedule. Also, sometimes the work is more data processing than working in a lab.

job_title: Visiting Assistant Professor in Champaign, IL
pros: Flexibility to push projects forward if self motivated. Good way to get experience in an area of interest and learn skills to move forward.
cons: The pay for this position was low, especially  considering the level of education required to complete projects. Welcome to the world of academics.

review_title: Can support yourself if you budget
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Champaign, IL
pros: Tuition reimbursement and partial fee waiver, can focus on full-time academic work, guaranteed for most of your educational program
cons: Only a 2% raise per year, must budget to save, must pay for professional development, must pay partial fees ($400-500 per semester, depending if you are on university insurance)

pros: You get the employee benefit meals! If you work a early lunch shift you only have to work for one and a half hours and you can have lunch for free in the dining hall.
cons: Some dinner shifts tend to be long and sometimes tiring. Also sometimes your cloth would get the smell of the food if you stay too long in the dining halls, and it could be annoying.

review_title: Good place for a postdoc to develop professional skills
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Urbana, IL
pros: There are quite a few professors open for collaboration. If you are anexprimentalist, there is a large amount of fabrication and characterization equipment, which is well maintained. The administration is usually very supportive.
cons: Overhead is almost 100%, so grants are spent pretty quickly. Health insurance is fairly expensive and continues to increase. The campus is very nice, but location-wise it is rather far from large cities.

pros: The most thing I liked about the place is its flexible work hours, academic holidays and vacation, and its diverse and family-like work environment where people cares each other. People come from diverse cultural background making everyday more interesting.
cons: Academic environment doesn't often come with the best innovation, and often time daily work can be little boring I guess. Then people would get less motivated for their work and career growth.

pros: There are plenty of opportunities to grow within IBC. Everyone starts out as a consultant, even advanced degree candidates, but IBC really gives you a sense of what Consulting in the real world is like especially when dealing with real clients.
cons: Does not pay their consultants, experienced consultants, or project managers.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Urbana, IL
pros: The 50% appointment gave me a full tuition waiver, medical insurance, and paid paid most fees.  My supervisor was very accommodating.
cons: Like most public institutions it is underfunded and poorly led.  People rise to their level of administrative incompetence.  One's advance is limited by possession of a PhD rather than real ability.  There are a lot of unimaginative, not very smart people with PhDs.

review_title: Messy environment with the perception of professionalism
pros:
-Paid a decent hourly wage for a graduate student
-I enjoyed meeting with some of the students
-Looks impressive on a resume
cons:
-The management is very relational
-They give you too much work to be done in the weekly 10 hour time limit

review_title: Good pay in Crop Sciences for a teaching assistant
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Urbana, IL
pros:
-compensation in Crop Sciences was 
-assistantship was voluntary, so I didn't have to rely on it, which arguably raises the quality of teaching
-opportunity to directly teach students, not just grade
-being an international student did not slow things down (working actually had the benefit of providing me with a SSN, non-resident tax treaty benefits)
cons:
-It's a teaching assistantship.  Don't expect to get that much.
-grading sucks

job_title: Teaching Appointments in Los Gatos, CA
pros: Students are motivated and goal driven. They work better in a group because they can try to teach each other, and be competitive in learning the materials.
cons: The st patrics day unofficial friday is a desaster. Some of them just came in to discuss drunk. But most of them just skip that day's classes.

review_title: University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign is a great school
pros: One of the top 5 ECE and CS Depts in the U.S. Great faculty and staff. New ECE and CS buildings are fantastic.  Also, has top School of Music, pioneer in electronic/music with new Music Tech program and new joint program with Computer Science.
cons: Needs to solve the football/basketball problem.

pros: The work culture in the UIUC Physics Department is very good. People are cooperative and everyone wants to help each with other. I do not recall witnessing any cutthroat behavior.
cons: It's academia so the perverse incentives like grants and prestigious publications applies. I experienced a lot of anxiety because of this, but this is a problem in general in academia not specific to UIUC.

review_title: Well, overall it was quite pleasant. The faculties are nice, the students are smart, and the workload is fair.
pros: The price of living at this place is quite low compared to other major cities in the states. However, the weather is too cold in the winter.
cons: The location makes the opportunities of getting hired fairly small since it is in the mid-west, though there are some local companies around in this area.

pros: There are plenty of resources and knowledgeable peers who you can use and consult. The atmosphere is good.
cons: There are less available opportunities for international students compared school in California and east coast.

pros: Competent/nice people who seem to enjoy their job.  A good environment that is social but not distracting, or intrusive
cons: The office is full of fairly fresh employees that do not have a lot of experience.  There are still some outdated workflow issues, that cause some bottlenecks.

pros: You can work with world class researchers and collaborate with most talented colleagues here at UIUC. You will definitely learn a lot.
cons: Life here is boring, especially in the summer. You will be living in a small town which is a center of nowhere.

pros: There is a lot of potential within the University, unfortunately all the red tape severely restricts how far you can make it with projects.
cons: Software-wise, everything takes so long to get approved that, by the time the software is released, it's already outdated. So the tools offered within the University  are constantly outdated.

review_title: Plenty of research opportunities and enthusiastic PI's
job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in Urbana, IL
pros: The PI I worked for was truly invested in me and helped me learn a lot. I felt supported, and the lab group had a great dynamic. I was encouraged to be challenged and take on research opportunities outside of the lab as well.
cons: The pay for an hourly undergraduate assistant can be less than the pay would be if you apply through a program.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Urbana, IL
pros: excellent place to work, smart people to work with, very good centers to collaborate with in different projects, leading edge research...
cons: urbana is a small town, no hills or ocean near by, even though the school is amazing the people in town are somewhat ignorant, weather (winter time)

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Champaign, IL
pros:
- Great place to work
- Many opportunities to grow
- Very good health coverage
-  Very smart people around you to help you learn
- In general there is a lot of flexibility
cons: Virtually none. And that is a bad thing. Sometimes the job can get a bit monotonic, so you should be willing to take initiative and discover new collaboration opportunities.The campus is a bit distant from any major city center.

pros: Diverse community. Great work/life balance. Opportunity to be creative. Not very stressful. My job allows me to work remotely, as does AITS.
cons:
Corrupt state government, funding keeps getting cut, best jobs are grant funded. 
Flat topography, rising crime, public schools are meh. Transfers within the university rarely get a raise of more then 10%. Pensions are about to get cut significantly.

pros: You are paid to attend a class and take notes as well as preparation time for each session. The direct supervisor is great and understanding.
cons: Few of the people you work with aren't fully there. They don't do there job at times and just seemed to hate their job.

review_title: One of the most fun and fulfilling jobs I've had thus far in my life.
job_title: Assistant Team Leader in Urbana, IL
pros: Simple job for students, the people are easy to get along with, only work with fellow students, job duties are easy to fulfill, schedule can be worked around or traded easily within.
cons: Late hours, environment can make it feel stagnant or narrow-focused, and guidelines can be vague.

pros: Environment provides a lot of latitude to develop and grow expertise and to make "the job your own". Extremely flexible environment provided you take care of your work duties. Very pleasant and knowledgeable colleauges.
cons: Like all universities a rather conservative university in terms of being forward thinking and on the cutting edge. Challenging environment to work in if you want to make progress rapidly.

review_title: Great place for grad school, but the faculty can be a little pretentious
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Champaign, IL
pros: UIUC is one of the best schools in the world for any engineering discipline.
cons: Many professors at Illinois seem to think that UIUC is the only school in the world worth going to. There's a lot of elitism, which really drives me crazy. This place is a bubble. Academics here can be really out of touch with reality.

review_title: Management is scared to train and cultivate
pros: Job security, vacation, sick time.
cons: Lower pay than private sector, retirement  and other benefits in jeopardy due to state fiscal crisis.  Management typically doesn't cultivate it's people for some general fear that the employee will learn and leave.

review_title: Illinois Natural History Survey Digital Technician Assistant
job_title: Digital Technician Assistant in Champaign, IL
pros: I worked on entering label data on the organism of interest to the database. The database is the collegiate portal and typing the label data into a form. The payroll was good and the people in the lab was great.
cons: You do the rote typing with a detail-oriented work.  A little far from campus.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Champaign, IL
pros: vital academic community that features world class research in a number of areas; smart students, even if they do tend to be over-privileged
cons: Very low pay as a graduate teaching assistant.  Basically subsistence-level pay for doing the primary work of teaching students, which many professors try to avoid.

review_title: Glad I am in grad school
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Urbana, IL
pros: Great educational opportunities, nice town, great benefits, fair pay given the valuable training you have the opportunity to receive.
cons: The hours you work and the quality of your work do not correlate with your stipend- but this is typical of grad school anywhere.

review_title: Great experience! Great boss, helpful HR department.
pros:
-I love my boss. This obviously depends on who you work for, but my boss is helpful and flexible.
-The office in Beckman that helps you set up direct deposits, tax forms, etc. is super helpful and always replies to emails promptly.
-The Beckman facility is state-of-the-art and a lovely environment in which to work.
cons: I do not dislike anything about working for UIUC.

pros: Working concessions gives you the chance to choose your hours. You often get to choose which events you would like to work. The people you work with are great and the supervisor is awesome.  Free food!
cons: You will gain weight from all the concession food you eat.  It can be a pain dealing with customers and you have to wear a hat.

pros: Great work environment, very relaxed as long as you meet work expectations. The vacation time and benefits are terrific, and Champaign is a great community. I've been allowed an above-average amount of technical freedom in choosing how to execute the projects I'm on.
cons: Collaboration is almost non-existent, most employees pursuing their own projects. Path for employee advancement is vague from management. Office is quiet, bring headphones :)

pros: Got to work with students and faculty so it was a friendly environment. Boss was nice and understanding, chill environment.
cons: Boring but it kind of came with the job. Nothing really to get hyped about, it was just helping people with computer issues.

pros: great university, dedicated instructors, great place to study that you can have quiet and clam environment
cons: the location is far away from major cities, although the university have career fair each year and lots of big names come to the fair, students here still lack of enough network opportunities with potential employers.

review_title: It's about what you would expect from a training program.
pros: Thorough and high quality training with experts in their fields. Proven success rates with trainees. Diversity of work experience is unmatched.
cons: Extremely long hours and very high, often difficult to meet work standards. Often undervalued as a clearly integral part of workforce.

pros: It is a very professional working environment to work at with a great numbers of scholars, researchers, professors, and students.
cons: It could be better located in near bigger city, Chicago. It takes two and a half hour to get to a major city.

review_title: As a student worker at a residence hall, I am very satisfied with my on-campus job at UIUC.
pros: Very flexible work schedule. Minimal tasks to do at the beginning of a shift. After completing your tasks, you can do whatever you want at the desk such as homework or study.
cons: Sometimes you get stuck working late night/early morning shifts.

pros: Flexible schedule, little to no micromanagement, rewarding to interact with clients and advance their research, get to interact with many types of people.
cons: CFO is trying to outsource all IT to a 3rd party call center. Therefore, leadership isn't the greatest at the current time.

pros:
Flexibility in work hours
Good pay
Good benefits
Great people to work with
cons:
Lack of legislators passing a budget for two years (inadequate funding)
Too many highly paid upper administration positions
Need more transparency from the President on down

pros:
boss isn't breaking down your neck like in some other industries
fun atmosphere since you work with other students most of the time
cons:
minimum wage
some of the library facilities can be a bit stifling, especially in the east wing
hard work went unnoticed by management

pros: Very flexible work hours depending on which students you work for; you can work as many or as few hours as you would like
cons: The administrators have no idea how to do their jobs properly. In general, they are out of touch with the employees and the students living in the program.

job_title: Ph D Student in Urbana, IL
pros: There is nothing to do except working on your research. Cost of living (rent, food etc) is very cheap. Really good engineering and physics depts, awesome guest speakers.
cons: There is nothing to do except working on your research. Chicago is 2.5 hrs away. Noisy and annoying undergrads. Phd professors are a weird breed. Only go to grad school if you are positive you want a PhD.

review_title: Large university with a lot of support for Grad students. Diverse fields of excellence to get exposed to,
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Urbana, IL
pros: Friendly college town atmosphere. Far away from the hustle and bustle of a big city environment. Compensation is sufficient for basic lifestyle needs of a Grad student
cons: In many fields UIUC sacrifices quality for quantity, excellence for numbers. In part this is due to the obligations of being a public university.

review_title: Great if you're working for the right dept.
pros: Good pay, good coworkers, many opportunities to find other employment within the university.
cons: Very much a hierarchical position, opinions of GAs aren't heard by higher-ups due to rank. However, this depends on supervisors and naturally varies throughout the university.

pros: Good for students without a lot of time outside of studying, you don't need to grade the student's labs (lon capa grades everything for you).  You are responsible for doing the homework that the students do as well.
cons: Sometimes there isn't as much instruction so you may feel lost, but you just need to reach out to another TA or your supervisors.

pros:
nice job,... learn  a lot while getting paid enough to sustain yourself

Being a grad student is the best thing of both worlds..
cons:
none that I can think of, really.  

Pay is less. but then, you are getting your degree, so cant really complain too much..

job_title: Research Data Analyst in Champaign, IL
pros: Everyone was easy to work with and was passionate about their roles. We were able to choose our own hours, making finishing the projects very easy and timely.
cons: What was expected wasn't always clear. It would take some time for the Professors to relay this information to the grad students, who then relayed it to the interns.

review_title: The university of Illinois at Urbana Champaign is a great place to work.
pros: This job does not require much work and is very relaxed. Get raises every semester even though pay is minimum at work.
cons: Can't think of much besides having to work a minimum of hours per week. Conflicts with school schedule but you can get shifts subbed out.

pros: There are a lot of good resources on campus and I've learned a lot so far as an EE student here.
cons: A lot of the classes seem really disorganized and aren't set up to help you succeed.

review_title: A good place to be doing research
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Urbana, IL
pros: There is a great deal of support, with facilities for almost any experiment you want to do and expertise in almost any field.
cons: It's in corn country. The HR requirements are the same for limited contract employees like postdocs as they are for permanent ones, which ends up not making a lot of sense for things like retirement benefits.

pros: Benefits, experience, collection, salary, work-life balance, cost of living, community, affordable housing, job opportunities for spouses, autonomy, low crime, job security.
cons: Stressful, bad drivers (students), class system (not everyone equal), out of date technology, little IT support, state budget, health care, winters.

job_title: UGL Student Assistant in Urbana, IL
pros:
- Like I said, very considerate of student schedules
- Pays more than min wage, which is unusual in Urbana and more than I expected from the university
- Really friendly work environment
cons:
- Clear favoritism among workers
- Mandatory overnight shifts during finals and midterms
- Favoritism again - the favors done and leeway given by supervisors to certain SAs can be super transparent

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Urbana, IL
pros: Review all the fundamental theories and labs in heat transfer and fluid mechanics. Practice on communication skills and class arrangement. Make friends with people of the same age and same research interests.
cons: Take much time to prepare for the lectures, debugging experiment devices and grading reports. Less flexibility on the schedule so you cannot register or audit more than 3 courses.

review_title: Great work opportunity while studying at the University
pros: Great management staff that were always willing to help with any and all issues, and were also understanding of class commitments that might interfere with work.
cons: Some of the projects can become long and tedious and dealing with the extensive and exhausting rules/regulations the campus has is annoying.

review_title: Graduate Research Assistant within Civil Engineering Department
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Urbana, IL
pros: Great school to get a masters degree in civil engineering. Research work depends on your advisor. Some advisors will work you into the ground others will be extremely chill.
cons: They don't pay you in the month of August and many times the work will overload you, but you get a free degree basically.

job_title: Help Desk Computer Consultant in Urbana, IL
pros:
- customer services job
- if there's none coming for help, you can just do your hw (but no Netflix) -- however there's a phone queue and email queue, so i never actually see this case.
cons:
- I just not into it so much
- at the beginning of semester, there are numerous people coming for help desk... Tiring
- paid is around $9/hr

job_title: Resident Advisor-Graduate Housing in Urbana, IL
pros: Awesome opportunities to program and plan, awesome unique residents, great management that understands you are a student first, very good training, awesome because free meal plan and housing.
cons: Sometimes can be difficult to manage job and schoolwork but overall easy to get organized and time manage as you develop experience

review_title: Work hard, but love what I do
pros: Passionate colleagues, Supportive work environment, Independence to lead and develop projects, Great students to work with, Many opportunities for professional development & growth.
cons: So many great opportunities for interesting work, but get pulled into so many things... often get spread too thin, and it can be stressful to keep up. They can ask a lot of you.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Champaign, IL
pros:
-Great people, social department depending on lab group
-Good department leadership
-Instructors are good, class level appropriate for program
cons:
-Limited money, you have to be creative with your advisor to make sure you have funding for your whole time in graduate school
-Relationships with University level leadership is strained (took many months for the Graduate Employee Union to negotiate a new contract)

review_title: As a student working for the university...
job_title: Student IT Technician in Urbana, IL
pros: Easy to work around class schedule and exam times, understanding supervisors, get a more intimate and behind-the-scenes view of university operations, decent compensation
cons: Hours limited from 9-5 on weekdays (difficult to work many as a student in those hours), occasionally dealing with hostile faculty (blame for technical difficulties)

pros: The interview went for an hour and just some basic behavioural questions like why this position, why we hire you, how to deal with conflicts were asked. People here are awesome---hilarious, easy-going and caring! The office is lovely and welcoming! Definitely had a great time working there and improved a lot my problem solving skills.
cons: None of disadvantages working here found.

job_title: Portfolio Management Intern in Champaign, IL
pros: Excellent people to work with. Would always encourage you to try new things and bring something new at the desk. Excellent work life balance and great compensation. Seniors and colleagues are very talented and someone you can always look up to for any advice.
cons: I personally don't think that I have faced any problems or issues while working at the endowment

pros: Tony Hillen is the best boss I've ever had, and working in the School of Social work is an absolute joy.
cons: Sometimes the tasks seem very trivial and grunt like, but it comes along with the job description and it's absolutely fine.

job_title: Engineering IT Student Consultant in Urbana, IL
pros: I used to work there as a student, and it is an on campus job. I worked with many full time stuff there and I think the pros is that their jobs are boring a lot.
cons: If you like a boring but easy job, then this is good to u

job_title: Acct Tech II in Champaign, IL
pros: Bosses have been fantastic! Co-workers are good. Perhaps I have been lucky but things have been good.
cons: Most clerical positions are bargained by the union which as done nothing for me- actually has held me back. State of the state is a bit wonky and causes some concern.

review_title: My experience at this institution has been one of diversity and rapid change.
pros: The best reasons to work at this University is because with a annual renewal of students networking never ends.
cons: The downside to working at this campus are the harsh winters.

review_title: good environment for CS research but Profs as you to do non-sense engineering for them
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Champaign, IL
pros: You get to do research at a top university. There are a lot of good professors to learn from.
cons: My professor is starting a company from the software base created initially for research and he asks for engineering work for it. As a grad student you have no choice!

pros: The leadership experience as a teaching assistant in the resume really shines when hunting for a job. Working as a TA is not as difficult as it seems, but there will be a lot of interactions with the students.
cons: Take a lot of time to work with students, the compensation is a by hour base, at least for undergraduate students.

pros:
The best work-life balance I've ever experienced.
Flexible work hours - Sometimes I show up as late as 11AM and it's fine
Amazing paid leave - 24 vacation days, 25 sick days
cons: Government budget cuts mean people will probably get laid off, and get less benefits in the near future (less travel, less retirement, etc)

pros: Good re-learn experience, provide tuition waiver and contact with interesting students and other TAs.
cons: Sometimes workload too much, need to check and reply a lot of emails every day and also need to answer questions online.

pros: Supportive committee members who were willing to help out in any way; Intellectual freedom to conduct research in topic of interest
cons: A competitive environment with a lack of support from other peers; Department may favor hard sciences and some students based on awards given; Working area was small, hot during the summer, crowded and loud due to construction and hallway conversations.

pros: The schedule is flexible and you can do homework on the job. The staff is incredible and you get to meet really awesome people. I truly loved my job at Grainger, and it was one of my best college experiences.
cons: The pay is lower is you work during the day, but there are opportunities to work at night for more pay.

pros: As a full-time student, working  as an RA would waive my tuition fee and give me salary every month to cover most of my living expenses. Besides, I could gain more knowledge by doing research in lab.
cons: Being an RA really cost time. I feel great pressure from my director and I am not quite into my topic

review_title: Undergraduate experience in the computer science department
pros: The computer science department at UIUC is very competitive. Professors are nice and easy to approach. UIUC also has very nicely structured curriculum. Most of the classes are useful.
cons: Sometimes the workload is too heavy. Be careful when you decide to take four computer science classes in one semester. Classes can be very demanding.

job_title: I-STAR (Illinois Student Admissions Representative) in Champaign, IL
pros: Being an I-STAR is a fun job and really helps you to hone your people skills as well as being able to make people's day while sharing information about a place that you love.
cons: Can be very bureaucratic as it is a government institution.  This position is not for those who don't like being a student at Illinois.

pros:
- Very intelligent people
- Friendly environment 
- Diverse academic backgrounds 
- Large campus means lots of opportunities to mingle
cons:
- Food is not as high quality as other campuses 
- Campus is isolated from other large cities
- Harsh winters can be uncomfortable to those who aren't acclimated

pros: You get the chance to interact with an enormous amount of diverse and smart people who are friendly and willing to help.
cons: Middle of nowhere Illinois, it is certainly far from many other places, and it is a rural town surrounded by corn and soybean plantations.

review_title: A great place to work on campus
pros: Great experience for students who're familiar with PC's and related tech. On campus location with easy-access from just about anywhere with bus routes right outside. The people of the SSW are fantastic; both the staff and faculty create an ideal working environment.
cons: None to report, employment here was fantastic.

review_title: Great benefits, stress-free job, salary less than what you can get elsewhere
pros: Benefits are ridiculously good. 26 paid vacation days every year, Medical insurance costs about $60/month for 100% coverage, Tuition waivers for any classes you want to take in the University system.
cons: Salary is lower than what you can get elsewhere, and advancement is not as easy to come by.

job_title: Ph D Graduate Student in Urbana, IL
pros: Research opportunities and resources, collaborative work, college town, large campus offering numerous activities and access to sporting events, great cost of living

pros:

Easygoing people working with you.
Straightforward Management.

review_title: Graduate Research Assistant at University of Illinois
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Urbana, IL

pros: The University of Illinois at Urbana Champaign is a major research institution that provides copious opportunities for students and staff alike.
cons: winters anywhere (east of the southwest!) can be harsh. An Illinois winter is no exception. So bundle up. Don your boots, mittens and down jackets. Grin and bear it. Go Illini!

pros: Quite possibly the best reason to work on campus at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign is the people. You can learn a lot in a job, but it's the people you interact with everyday that make all the difference.
cons: Due to this position being part-time, I was unable to get the level of hands-on experience wanted.

job_title: Business Administrative Associate in Urbana, IL

cons: SURS retirement is always changing, and leaves you feeling unsettled about what the future holds. Changes seem borderline illegal. Annual salary increases are based on the campus salary program which ends up being between 0-3%, in the last 10 years it's been averaging 0-2%, and not matching inflation.

review_title: Nice place to work.... but not much else.
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Urbana, IL

cons: Horrible HR issue in signing up for benefits - had to run across campus from building to building just to find the right forms and signatures. Was not advised on new employee opportunities/training (had to learn how to get a mailbox, keys, building access, basic things).

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Urbana, IL

Chance to go on for dietetic internship

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Champaign, IL

review_title: For a university job experience, it has been pretty good

review_title: Unparalleled experience in a highly motivated environment

review_title: Great place to learn everyday and contribute as well
